name: Patmos
shortDescription: Greek island in the Aegean Sea where Saint John received the apocalyptic visions recorded in the Book of Revelation, now a major Christian pilgrimage site.
fullDescription: Patmos is a small Greek island in the southeastern Aegean Sea, one of the northernmost islands of the Dodecanese complex. This rocky, volcanic island, measuring only about 34 square kilometers, achieved eternal significance when Saint John the Evangelist was exiled here during the reign of Emperor Domitian (c. 95 CE). In a cave on the island, John received the extraordinary visions that became the Book of Revelation, Christianity's definitive apocalyptic text. The island is mentioned directly in Revelation 1:9: 'I John, who also am your brother, and companion in tribulation...was in the isle that is called Patmos, for the word of God, and for the testimony of Jesus Christ.' According to tradition, John dictated his visions to his disciple Prochorus in what is now called the Cave of the Apocalypse (Grotto of the Revelation). The Byzantine Monastery of Saint John the Theologian, founded in 1088 by Saint Christodoulos, crowns the island's highest point and houses important manuscripts and relics. UNESCO designated the historic center of Patmos, including the Monastery and Cave, as a World Heritage Site in 1999. The island remains a major pilgrimage destination for Christians worldwide, who come to venerate the site where the final book of the Bible was revealed.

sacredSites.description: Byzantine monastery founded 1088, fortress-like structure on highest point. Houses important manuscripts, icons, and John's relics.

mythologyContexts.usage: Patmos represents the place where heaven opened and divine secrets were revealed to humanity through John. Despite being a place of exile and suffering, it became the site of Christianity's greatest prophetic revelation. The island embodies the Christian theme of God working through persecution and isolation to accomplish His purposes.

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Patmos symbolizes the intersection of exile and revelation, suffering and glory, earthly limitation and heavenly vision. The small, isolated island becomes a cosmic threshold where heaven's secrets are unveiled. The cave represents both constraint (exile) and womb (birth of apocalyptic vision). The island embodies how God transforms places of punishment into sites of prophetic encounter.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Patmos is one of Christianity's holiest pilgrimage sites, visited by Orthodox, Catholic, and Protestant Christians. The island's identity is inseparable from John's revelation, with religious tourism forming a major part of its economy. The Cave and Monastery preserve the memory of the apocalyptic encounter. Patmos represents Christian hope that God speaks through human suffering and that exile cannot silence divine communication.
